description: Loads, spans, foundations, framing, structural engineering basics

questions.question: What is a dead load?

options.text: The permanent weight of the structure and fixed elements

questions.explanation: Dead loads are permanent, stationary loads including the weight of the building structure, floors, walls, roofs, and fixed equipment. They don't change over time.

questions.question: What is a live load?

options.text: Temporary loads from occupants, furniture, and movable items

questions.explanation: Live loads are temporary and movable, including people, furniture, equipment, and stored materials. They vary based on occupancy and use.

questions.question: What is the minimum uniformly distributed live load for residential sleeping areas?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Table 1607.1, residential sleeping areas require a minimum live load of 30 pounds per square foot (psf).

questions.question: What is the minimum uniformly distributed live load for residential living areas?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Table 1607.1, residential living areas (other than sleeping areas) require a minimum live load of 40 psf.

questions.question: What is the minimum live load for a residential deck?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Table 1607.1, exterior balconies and decks in residential occupancies require a minimum live load of 40 psf, same as interior living areas.

questions.question: What is the minimum live load for office areas?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Table 1607.1, office space requires a minimum live load of 50 psf.

questions.question: What is a lateral load?

options.text: Horizontal load such as wind or seismic

questions.explanation: Lateral loads act horizontally on a structure, primarily from wind and seismic (earthquake) forces. Buildings must resist these loads to remain stable.

questions.question: What is uplift?

options.text: Upward force that can lift the roof or structure

questions.explanation: Uplift is an upward force, typically from wind, that can lift the roof off the walls or the structure off its foundation. Proper connections resist uplift.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a load path?

options.text: The continuous connection that transfers loads from roof to foundation

questions.explanation: The load path is the continuous chain of structural members and connections that transfers all loads (gravity and lateral) from where they originate down to the foundation.

questions.question: What is a point load?

options.text: A load spread over an area
A concentrated load applied at a single location

questions.explanation: A point load (concentrated load) is applied at a specific location rather than distributed over an area. Examples include columns bearing on beams or posts on footings.

questions.question: What is a uniformly distributed load?

options.text: A load spread evenly over an area or length

questions.explanation: A uniformly distributed load is spread evenly over an area (psf) or length (plf). Floor live loads are typically expressed as uniform loads.

questions.question: What does 'psf' stand for in structural loading?
questions.explanation: PSF stands for pounds per square foot, a unit of pressure used to express uniformly distributed loads over an area.

questions.question: What does 'plf' stand for in structural loading?
questions.explanation: PLF stands for pounds per linear foot, a unit of load used to express uniformly distributed loads along a length, such as on a beam.

questions.question: How are snow loads determined?

options.text: Based on ground snow load and roof factors

questions.explanation: Per IBC 1608, snow loads are based on ground snow load (from maps), modified by factors for roof slope, exposure, thermal conditions, and importance.

questions.question: What is a tributary area?

options.text: The floor area whose load is carried by a specific member

questions.explanation: Tributary area is the portion of a floor or roof that loads a particular structural member. It's used to calculate the total load on beams, columns, and footings.

questions.question: What is bearing capacity?

options.text: The maximum pressure soil can support without failure

questions.explanation: Bearing capacity is the maximum pressure that soil can support without excessive settlement or shear failure. It's measured in pounds per square foot (psf).

questions.question: What is the presumptive bearing capacity for sandy gravel soil?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Table 1806.2, sandy gravel and/or gravel (GW and GP) has a presumptive bearing capacity of 3,000 psf.

questions.question: What is the presumptive bearing capacity for clay soil?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Table 1806.2, clay, sandy clay, silty clay, and clayey silt (CL, ML, MH, CH) has a presumptive bearing capacity of 1,500 psf.

questions.question: What is settlement?

options.text: Vertical downward movement of a structure due to soil compression

questions.explanation: Settlement is the vertical downward displacement of a foundation or structure as the soil beneath compresses under the applied load. Excessive or uneven settlement causes structural problems.

questions.question: What is differential settlement?

options.text: Even settling of the entire building
Unequal settling of different parts of a foundation

questions.explanation: Differential settlement occurs when different parts of a foundation settle by different amounts. This causes structural distress, cracking, and can lead to failure.

questions.question: What is expansive soil?

options.text: Soil that swells when wet and shrinks when dry

questions.explanation: Expansive soils contain clay minerals that absorb water and swell significantly. When they dry, they shrink. This movement can damage foundations and structures.

questions.question: What is a spread footing?

options.text: A shallow foundation that spreads load over a larger soil area

questions.explanation: A spread footing is a shallow foundation that widens at the base to distribute the building load over a larger area of soil, reducing bearing pressure.

questions.question: What is a continuous (strip) footing?

options.text: A footing that runs continuously under a wall

questions.explanation: A continuous or strip footing runs along the length of a wall to support it, distributing the wall load to the soil below.

questions.question: What is the minimum footing thickness for residential construction?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R403.1.1, continuous footings shall be a minimum of 6 inches thick.

questions.question: What is a pier foundation?

options.text: A column-like deep foundation that transfers loads to deeper soil or bedrock

questions.explanation: A pier foundation is a deep foundation consisting of a column-like element that extends down to competent soil or rock to support the structure above.

questions.question: When are deep foundations typically required?

options.text: When surface soils cannot support the load or have low bearing capacity

questions.explanation: Deep foundations (piles, piers, caissons) are used when shallow foundations aren't feasible due to poor surface soil, high loads, or other conditions requiring bearing on deeper strata.

questions.question: What is frost heave?

options.text: Upward movement of soil caused by freezing water

questions.explanation: Frost heave occurs when water in soil freezes and expands, pushing the soil and any structures above it upward. Footings below frost depth prevent this.

questions.question: Why must footings extend below the frost line?

options.text: To prevent frost heave from lifting the foundation

questions.explanation: Per IRC R403.1.4, footings must extend below the frost line to prevent damage from frost heave, which can lift and crack foundations.

questions.question: What is compressive strength of concrete measured in?
questions.explanation: Concrete compressive strength is measured in pounds per square inch (psi). Standard residential concrete is typically 2,500 to 3,000 psi.

questions.question: What is the typical curing time for concrete to reach design strength?
questions.explanation: Concrete typically reaches its design compressive strength at 28 days. At 7 days, it typically has about 70% of its 28-day strength.

questions.question: Why is reinforcing steel (rebar) used in concrete?

options.text: To provide tensile strength that concrete lacks

questions.explanation: Concrete is strong in compression but weak in tension. Steel reinforcement provides tensile strength, making reinforced concrete strong in both compression and tension.

questions.question: What does a #4 rebar designation mean?
questions.explanation: Rebar sizes are designated by the number of eighths of an inch in diameter. A #4 bar is 4/8" = 1/2" (0.5") in diameter.

questions.question: What is the purpose of concrete cover over rebar?

options.text: To protect rebar from corrosion and provide fire resistance

questions.explanation: Concrete cover protects reinforcing steel from corrosion due to moisture, provides bond between concrete and steel, and provides fire resistance.

questions.question: What is the water-cement ratio?

options.text: The ratio of water to aggregate
The ratio of water weight to cement weight
The percentage of water in concrete

questions.explanation: The water-cement ratio is the weight of water divided by the weight of cement in a concrete mix. Lower ratios produce stronger, more durable concrete.

questions.question: What is slump in concrete?
questions.explanation: Slump measures concrete workability - how easily it flows. It's tested by filling a cone, removing it, and measuring how much the concrete settles. Higher slump = more fluid.

questions.question: What is the actual dimension of a 2x4 lumber?
questions.explanation: Nominal 2x4 lumber has actual dimensions of 1-1/2" x 3-1/2" after drying and surfacing. The nominal size refers to the rough-sawn dimension before processing.

questions.question: What is the actual dimension of a 2x10 lumber?
questions.explanation: Nominal 2x10 lumber has actual dimensions of 1-1/2" x 9-1/4" after drying and surfacing.

questions.question: What do lumber grade stamps indicate?

options.text: Species, grade, moisture content, and grading agency

questions.explanation: Grade stamps identify the wood species, structural grade (which affects allowable stresses), moisture content, and the grading agency certifying the lumber.

questions.question: What does SPF stand for in lumber?
questions.explanation: SPF stands for Spruce-Pine-Fir, a lumber species group commonly used for framing. It's a combination of these similar softwood species.

questions.question: What is pressure-treated lumber used for?

options.text: Applications in contact with ground or exposed to moisture

questions.explanation: Pressure-treated lumber has preservatives forced into the wood to resist decay and insects. It's required for sill plates, posts in contact with ground, and other moisture-exposed applications.

questions.question: What is an engineered wood product?

options.text: Manufactured wood products like LVL, I-joists, and glulam

questions.explanation: Engineered wood products are manufactured from wood strands, veneers, or lumber bonded with adhesives. They include LVL, glulam, I-joists, and wood structural panels with predictable properties.

questions.question: What is LVL?
questions.explanation: LVL (Laminated Veneer Lumber) is an engineered wood product made from thin wood veneers glued together with grain parallel. It's used for beams, headers, and rim boards.

questions.question: What is glulam?

options.text: Glued laminated timber made from lumber layers

questions.explanation: Glulam (glued laminated timber) is made by bonding layers of dimensional lumber together with adhesives. It's used for long-span beams and curved members.

questions.question: What is an I-joist?

options.text: An engineered floor joist with flanges and web

questions.explanation: I-joists are engineered floor joists shaped like the letter "I" with LVL or solid wood flanges and OSB or plywood web. They're lightweight, strong, and span long distances.

questions.question: What is deflection?
questions.explanation: Deflection is the amount a beam or other structural member bends or moves from its original position when load is applied. Building codes limit deflection to prevent damage and discomfort.

questions.question: What is the typical deflection limit for floor joists under live load?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Table 1604.3, the maximum deflection for floor members under live load is L/360, where L is the span length. This prevents bouncy or uncomfortable floors.

questions.question: What does L/360 deflection limit mean for a 15-foot span?
questions.explanation: L/360 means span divided by 360. For a 15-foot (180") span: 180"/360 = 0.5" maximum deflection. This fraction relates span to allowable movement.

questions.question: What is span in structural terms?
questions.explanation: Span is the clear distance between supports of a structural member. Longer spans require larger or stronger members to safely carry the load.

questions.question: What is a cantilevered beam?

options.text: A beam supported at both ends
A beam supported at one end extending beyond the support

questions.explanation: A cantilever is a beam or other member that extends beyond its support point and is loaded on the unsupported end. Balconies and deck overhangs are common examples.

questions.question: What is the maximum cantilever for floor joists without engineering?

options.text: Per the span tables (typically 1/4 to 1/3 of backspan)

questions.explanation: Per IRC R502.3.3, floor joists may cantilever per the span tables, typically limited to about 1/4 of the joist backspan, depending on species and size.

questions.question: What is the purpose of blocking between floor joists?

options.text: To prevent joist rotation and provide lateral support

questions.explanation: Blocking (solid blocking or bridging) between joists prevents rotation, provides lateral support, helps distribute loads, and stiffens the floor system.

questions.question: What is a rim joist (band joist)?

options.text: A joist in the middle of the floor
The perimeter joist that closes off the floor cavity

questions.explanation: The rim joist (or band joist) is the perimeter member that runs perpendicular to the floor joists and encloses the ends of the joist bays.

questions.question: What is a girder in floor framing?

options.text: A main beam that supports floor joists

questions.explanation: A girder is a primary structural beam that spans between foundation walls or columns and supports floor joists. It carries concentrated loads to the foundation.

questions.question: What is a sill plate?

options.text: The wood member anchored to the foundation that supports the floor system

questions.explanation: The sill plate (mudsill) is the horizontal wood member attached to the top of the foundation wall that supports floor joists and transfers loads to the foundation.

questions.question: What is a header in wall framing?

options.text: A beam over an opening that supports loads above

questions.explanation: A header is a horizontal beam placed over door, window, or other openings in load-bearing walls to transfer loads from above around the opening to the studs on each side.

questions.question: What is a king stud?

options.text: A stud next to a corner
The full-height stud on each side of an opening that supports the header

questions.explanation: King studs are the full-height studs on each side of a door or window opening. They run from the bottom plate to the top plate and support the header.

questions.question: What is a jack stud (trimmer stud)?

options.text: The shortened stud that supports the header from below

questions.explanation: Jack studs (trimmers) are the shortened studs next to king studs that run from the bottom plate to the underside of the header, directly supporting its ends.

questions.question: What is a cripple stud?

options.text: A short stud above or below an opening

questions.explanation: Cripple studs are the short studs that fill in above headers or below window sills. They maintain stud spacing for sheathing attachment and load transfer.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a double top plate?

options.text: To tie walls together and support joists or rafters

questions.explanation: The double top plate ties intersecting walls together, provides a continuous horizontal member, supports floor/ceiling joists or rafters, and allows joints to be offset between plates.

questions.question: What is a shear wall?

options.text: A wall designed to resist lateral loads like wind and seismic

questions.explanation: A shear wall is a vertical element of the lateral force-resisting system that transfers lateral loads (wind, earthquake) from upper levels to the foundation through in-plane shear.

questions.question: What makes a wall a braced wall panel?

options.text: A wall section with structural sheathing or diagonal bracing that resists lateral loads

questions.explanation: Per IRC R602.10, braced wall panels are wall sections constructed to resist lateral forces using prescribed bracing methods like structural sheathing, let-in bracing, or portal frames.

questions.question: What is a rafter?

options.text: A sloped framing member that supports the roof

questions.explanation: Rafters are the sloped structural members that extend from the ridge or hip to the wall plate and support the roof sheathing and covering.

questions.question: What is the ridge board?

options.text: A non-structural board at the roof peak connecting rafter ends

questions.explanation: A ridge board is a non-structural horizontal member at the peak of the roof where the upper ends of opposing rafters meet and attach. It provides alignment and connection.

questions.question: What is a ridge beam?

options.text: A structural beam at the ridge that supports rafters

questions.explanation: A ridge beam is a structural member that actually supports the rafters from above, eliminating the need for ceiling joists to resist outward thrust. It requires posts for support.

questions.question: What is the purpose of ceiling joists in a conventional rafter roof?

options.text: To act as ties preventing rafters from pushing walls outward

questions.explanation: In conventional framing with a ridge board (not beam), ceiling joists act as tension ties connecting opposing rafters. They prevent the outward thrust from pushing walls apart.

questions.question: What is rafter thrust?

options.text: The outward horizontal force rafters exert on walls

questions.explanation: Rafter thrust is the outward horizontal force that sloped rafters exert on the walls when loaded. Ceiling joists, collar ties, or structural ridges resist this thrust.

questions.question: What is a collar tie?

options.text: A horizontal member connecting opposing rafters in the upper third

questions.explanation: Per IRC R802.4.1, collar ties are horizontal members connecting opposing rafters in the upper third of the roof. They help resist thrust and prevent rafter spread.

questions.question: What is roof pitch?

options.text: The rise in inches per 12 inches of horizontal run

questions.explanation: Roof pitch is expressed as rise over run, typically as X:12, meaning the roof rises X inches for every 12 inches of horizontal run. A 6:12 pitch rises 6 inches per foot.

questions.question: What is a truss?

options.text: A pre-engineered structural frame using triangulated members

questions.explanation: A truss is a prefabricated structural component using triangulated members (chords and webs) that act together to span long distances. They're designed by engineers for specific loads.

questions.question: Can trusses be modified or cut in the field?
questions.explanation: Trusses are engineered as complete systems. Cutting, notching, or modifying any member can cause failure. Any modification requires approval from a licensed engineer.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a hurricane tie?

options.text: To connect rafters/trusses to wall plates to resist uplift

questions.explanation: Hurricane ties (rafter ties) are metal connectors that strap rafters or trusses to the top plate, providing a continuous load path to resist wind uplift.

questions.question: What is a joist hanger?

options.text: A metal connector that supports joist ends against a beam or header

questions.explanation: Joist hangers are manufactured metal connectors that attach floor joists to headers, beams, or ledgers. They transfer vertical loads and resist withdrawal.

questions.question: What type of nail is required for joist hangers?

options.text: The specific nail type specified by the hanger manufacturer

questions.explanation: Joist hangers must be installed with the specific nail type, length, and quantity specified by the manufacturer. Using wrong fasteners reduces capacity.

questions.question: What is a post base connector?

options.text: A metal connector that anchors a post to concrete

questions.explanation: Post base connectors anchor wood posts to concrete foundations or piers, providing uplift resistance and keeping the post above the concrete to prevent moisture damage.

questions.question: What is a holddown?

options.text: A connector that resists overturning of shear walls

questions.explanation: Holddowns are heavy-duty metal connectors that resist overturning (rotation) of shear wall segments by anchoring studs to the foundation or floor below.

questions.question: What is toe-nailing?

options.text: Driving nails at an angle through one member into another

questions.explanation: Toe-nailing drives nails at an angle through the side of one member into another, commonly used to attach studs to plates or rafters to plates.

questions.question: What is a W-shape in structural steel?
questions.explanation: W-shapes (wide-flange beams) are the most common structural steel shapes, with an I-shaped cross-section where the flanges are parallel and wider than S-shapes.

questions.question: What does W12x26 mean?

options.text: Approximately 12 inches deep, weighing 26 pounds per foot

questions.explanation: Steel beam designations show the nominal depth and weight per linear foot. W12x26 is a wide-flange beam approximately 12" deep weighing 26 pounds per foot.

questions.question: Why must structural steel be fireproofed in many applications?

options.text: Steel loses strength at elevated temperatures

questions.explanation: Steel loses significant strength when heated. Fireproofing (spray-on, intumescent paint, or encasement) protects steel from reaching temperatures that cause structural failure in a fire.

questions.question: What is cold-formed steel framing?

options.text: Steel framing installed in cold weather
Steel members formed from sheet steel at room temperature

questions.explanation: Cold-formed steel (CFS) framing uses thin sheet steel bent into C-shapes and tracks at room temperature. It's an alternative to wood framing with consistent, non-combustible properties.

questions.question: What is a standard concrete masonry unit (CMU) size?
questions.explanation: Standard CMU has nominal dimensions of 8" x 8" x 16". Actual dimensions are 7-5/8" x 7-5/8" x 15-5/8" to allow for 3/8" mortar joints.

questions.question: What is grout in masonry construction?

options.text: A fluid concrete mix used to fill CMU cells

questions.explanation: Grout is a fluid mixture of cite, aggregate, and water used to fill the cells (cores) of concrete masonry units, encasing reinforcing steel and creating a solid structural element.

questions.question: What is a bond beam?

options.text: A reinforced, grouted horizontal course that acts as a beam

questions.explanation: A bond beam is a horizontal grouted course with continuous reinforcing steel that distributes loads, resists lateral forces, and ties the wall together.

questions.question: What is a lintel in masonry construction?

options.text: A beam over an opening that supports masonry above

questions.explanation: A lintel is a horizontal member (steel angle, precast concrete, or reinforced masonry) that spans over doors, windows, or other openings to support the masonry above.

questions.question: What is mortar in masonry construction?

options.text: A mixture used to bond masonry units together at joints

questions.explanation: Mortar is the material used in joints between masonry units. It bonds units together, fills gaps, and distributes stresses. Different types (M, S, N, O) have different strengths.

questions.question: What is structural sheathing?

options.text: Panel material that provides lateral resistance to framing

questions.explanation: Structural sheathing (plywood, OSB) is fastened to framing to resist lateral loads (wind, seismic) and distribute loads across the frame. It stiffens the structure.

questions.question: What does the APA trademark on plywood indicate?

options.text: The panel has been performance-tested and certified

questions.explanation: APA (The Engineered Wood Association) trademark indicates the panel has been manufactured by an APA member and meets quality standards for the specified grade and performance.

questions.question: What does 'span rating' on structural panels mean?

options.text: The maximum support spacing for floor/roof applications

questions.explanation: The span rating (like 32/16) indicates the maximum support spacing: 32" for roof and 16" for floor applications. This ensures adequate support for the panel.

questions.question: What is the minimum thickness for wall sheathing used for bracing?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R602.10, structural panel sheathing used for wall bracing typically requires minimum 7/16" thickness for Method 3 bracing, with specific nailing patterns.

questions.question: What is the edge nailing requirement for structural wall sheathing?
questions.explanation: Per IRC Table R602.3(3), structural sheathing requires 6" on center nailing at panel edges and 12" on center at intermediate supports for standard braced wall panels.

questions.question: What is the formula for calculating the load on a beam?

options.text: Total Load = Load per Area  Tributary Area

questions.explanation: Beam load is calculated by multiplying the unit load (psf) by the tributary area the beam supports. This gives the total load the beam must carry.

questions.question: How do you calculate footing size for a column?

options.text: Total load divided by soil bearing capacity

questions.explanation: Footing area = Total column load  Allowable soil bearing capacity. For example, 10,000 lbs  2,000 psf = 5 square feet minimum footing area.

questions.question: If a floor carries 50 psf live load and a beam has 10-foot tributarywidth, what is the load per linear foot on the beam?
questions.explanation: Load per linear foot = psf  tributary width = 50 psf  10 ft = 500 plf. This converts area load to a linear load on the beam.

questions.question: What is the total load on a 12-foot square footing if the column load is 24,000 lbs?
questions.explanation: The total load on the footing is the column load: 24,000 lbs. The footing size affects soil pressure (24,000  144 = 167 psf), not the total load.

questions.question: What is a floor or roof diaphragm?

options.text: A horizontal structural element that transfers lateral loads to shear walls

questions.explanation: A diaphragm is the floor or roof system acting as a large horizontal beam, collecting lateral loads (wind, seismic) and transferring them to vertical shear walls or frames.

questions.question: What makes a floor system act as a structural diaphragm?

options.text: Proper sheathing and nailing of panels to joists

questions.explanation: A diaphragm requires structural sheathing (plywood, OSB) properly nailed to joists and connected to shear walls. The nailing pattern determines diaphragm capacity.

questions.question: What is a retaining wall?

options.text: A wall that holds back soil or other materials

questions.explanation: A retaining wall resists lateral soil pressure, holding back earth at different elevations. It must resist overturning, sliding, and soil pressure.

questions.question: What is lateral earth pressure?

options.text: The horizontal force soil exerts against a retaining wall

questions.explanation: Lateral earth pressure is the horizontal force exerted by soil against a retaining structure. It increases with depth and depends on soil type and conditions.

questions.question: Why is drainage important behind retaining walls?

options.text: To prevent hydrostatic pressure buildup that increases load

questions.explanation: Per IBC 1807.4.3, water behind a retaining wall adds hydrostatic pressure, significantly increasing the lateral load. Proper drainage prevents this pressure buildup.

questions.question: When is structural engineering required?

options.text: When the structure exceeds prescriptive code limits or has unusual conditions

questions.explanation: Structural engineering is required when designs exceed prescriptive (cookbook) limits in the code, for unusual conditions, complex loading, or when specifically required by the building official.
